Incident Investigation:  Although no incidents involving regulated substances have occurred at the Facility in the last five years, an incident investigation program is in place.  The program includes investigation requirements and reporting and would be implemented in the event of an incident.

Employee Participation:  The Facility must rely upon the operational expertise and training of its employees at all levels and disciplines to ensure safe operations.  The Facility has implemented procedures regarding employee participation to ensure consideration of their knowledge and experience in all applicable areas of the prevention program.

Hot Work Permit:  With regard to hot work that may occur on or near the Anhydrous Ammonia Process, TSI Dixon has developed a written Hot Work Permit to document the evaluation of the fire prevention and protection requirements.

Contractor Safety:  The contractors used by the Facility for anhydrous ammonia delivery have been informed regarding the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to delivery of anhydrous ammonia to the TSI Dixon Facility.  The Facility has confirmed that the delivery contractors have provided the appropriate training to their drivers regarding the delivery of anhydrous ammonia.

In addition to the prevention program elements described above, the following chemical-specific prevention steps have been implemented.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
1.	FACILITY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE POLICY
The owners, management, and employees of the TSI, A Division of The Tremont Group, Inc. (TSI), Dixon Facility (Facility) at 7235 Tremont Road, Dixon, California 95620 are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia or aqua ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the Facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.  A detailed Consolidated Contingency Plan (CCP) has been developed and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release.

2.	FACILITY INFORMATION
¿	The Facility is a retail agricultural facility whose primary activity is the storage and sale of fertilizers in addition to the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to agricultural operations in Northern California.
¿	Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) and aqua ammonia are received, converted, stored, and distributed for direct application as crop production nutrients. 
¿	Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and stored in either an 18,000-gallon storage tank (bullet) or a 30,050-gallon storage tank.  The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia handled is 209,930 pounds.
¿	Aqua ammonia is produced from anhydrous ammonia and stored in a 10,000-gallon storage tank, an 18,000-gallon storage tank, or an 8,300 gallon storage tank at the site.  The maximum quantity of aqua ammonia handled is 265,535 pounds.

3.	THE WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO
Anhydrous Ammonia Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios.  The worst-case release scenario is the failure of the largest storage tank when filled to the greatest amount, which would release 131,288 pounds of anhydrous ammonia; this represents the volume of the largest storage tank administratively limited at 85% of capacity.  The alternative release scenario based on the hazard review (or a more plausible p

otential incident) is a release from a broken 2-inch diameter pipe with an increased wind speed and D stability modeling parameters.
Aqua Ammonia Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios.  The worst-case scenario is failure of the largest storage tank when filled to the greatest amount, which would release 131,670 pounds of aqua ammonia that forms a liquid pool.  The alternative release scenario based on the hazard review (or a more plausible potential incident) is a release from a pipe break modeled with an increased wind speed and D Stability modeling parameters.
 
4.	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM	
The Facility has implemented the following prevention program elements.

Safety Information:  TSI ensures that information concerning covered processes and regulated substances are up-to-date and available for review by employees.  The most recent review of safety information pertaining to the covered processes took place on November 6, 2013.

Hazard Review:  A hazard review of the ammonia processes is conducted every five years or as needed by changes in the processes.  The most recent update of the hazard review for the anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia processes was conducted on November 6, 2013.  Results indicate that no high risk hazards were identified through the hazard review update.
Operating Procedures:  Written standard operating procedures have been developed for the covered processes and are reviewed and revised as needed.  The operating procedures were last revised on October 2, 2013.

Training:  The TSI Facility staff, as well as The Tremont Group, Inc. (Tremont) corporate staff, understands that incidents involving the accidental release of regulated substances can be reduced by having trained operations and maintenance staff.  A training program, which incorporates specific operating procedures and safe work practices, is an essential element of an effective prevention program. 5.	FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia or aqua ammonia during the last five years resulting in death, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, or property or environmental damage.

6.	THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The facility's emergency response program is developed in accordance with Section 25503, Division 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code, Hazardous Materials Business Plan requirements.  The CCP was most recently updated on March 8, 2013 and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release of a regulated substance.

7.	PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Safety improvement is an on-going process at the Facility.  Periodic evaluations will be performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  Specific changes to the anhydrous ammonia or aqua ammonia processes at the Facility will be implemented as needed.
